text: A Principled Framework for Responsible Data Sharing Between
label: HH1

text: Humanitarian Organizations and Donors
label: TITLE

text: Humanitarian Data and Trust Initiative
label: HH1

text: March 2023
label: BODY

text: Background
label: HH3

text: In September 2020, the Humanitarian Data and Trust Initiative (HDTI) initiated a dialogue
label: BODY

text: process related to responsible data sharing between humanitarian organizations and donors.
label: BODY

text: The goal was to examine and build a common understanding around the objectives, risks and
label: BODY

text: constraints related to this type of data sharing in humanitarian action in order to develop a
label: BODY

text: framework for collective action in this area.
label: BODY

text: The dialogue consisted of two meetings convened through Wilton Park (in September 2020
label: BODY

text: and in September 2021 ), two pieces of independent research (conducted by the Global Public
label: BODY

text: Policy Institute and the University of Manchester in 2020-2021), and a series of stakeholder
label: BODY

text: consultations. This framework is the primary output of this process.
label: BODY

text: II.
label: HH1

text: Rationale and Context
label: BODY

text: Humanitarian organizations increasingly recognize incentives to collect and share
label: BODY

text: disaggregated data from their operations for various purposes such as improved coordination,
label: BODY

text: more efficient service provision, accountability and transparency. At the same time, they have to
label: BODY

text: ensure that data is exclusively used for humanitarian purposes and does not cause harm to
label: BODY

text: vulnerable populations. This requires collective action to mitigate the risks related to sharing
label: BODY

text: disaggregated data in and about humanitarian contexts. These risks include the risk of
label: BODY

text: re-identification, violations of the rights to privacy and data protection, data breaches, and the
label: BODY

text: potential use of data outside of humanitarian purposes.
label: BODY

text: 6 Fast, Larissa. 2022. Data Sharing Between Humanitarian Organizations and Donors: Toward Understanding and Articulating
label: BODY

text: Responsible Practice. NCHS Paper 06, April. Bergen: Norwegian Centre for Humanitarian Studies. Available here:
label: BODY

text: https://www.humanitarianstudies.no/resource/data-sharing-between-humanitarian-organisations-and-donors/
label: BODY

text: 5 Global Public Policy Institute, “Risks Associated with Humanitarian Data Sharing with Donors,” September 2021. Available here:
label: BODY

text: https://www.gppi.net/2021/09/06/data-sharing-with-humanitarian-donors.
label: BODY

text: 4 The Wilton Park Report is available here: https://www.wiltonpark.org.uk/wp-content/uploads/2021/07/WP1777V2-Report.pdf.
label: BODY

text: 3 For more information on the September 2020 meeting, see: “Responsible Data Sharing with Donors: Accountability, Transparency
label: BODY

text: and Data Protection in Humanitarian Action”, 17 - 18 September 2020. Available here:
label: BODY

text: https://www.wiltonpark.org.uk/wp-content/uploads/2020/08/WP1777V-Report-1.pdf
label: BODY

text: 2 Wilton Park is an executive agency of the UK Foreign, Commonwealth & Development Office (FCDO) providing a global forum for
label: BODY

text: strategic discussion.
label: BODY

text: 1 The Humanitarian Data and Trust Initiative was launched in 2020 by the Government of Switzerland, the International Committee of
label: BODY

text: the Red Cross (ICRC) and the United Nations Office for Coordination of Humanitarian Affairs (UN OCHA) Centre for Humanitarian
label: BODY

text: Data. Learn more here: https://centre.humdata.org/introducing-the-humanitarian-data-and-trust-initiative/
label: BODY

text: Donors have an important role in the humanitarian data ecosystem, both as drivers of increased
label: BODY

text: data collection and analysis, and as direct users of data. In recent years, donors have begun to
label: BODY

text: increasingly request various forms of disaggregated data, such as household-level survey
label: BODY

text: results and data about the delivery of assistance disaggregated by demographics, geographical
label: BODY

text: location and/or group dimensions (e.g. ethnicity, protection status, etc.).
label: BODY

text: Concerns around requests for such data have led humanitarian organizations and donors to
label: BODY

text: develop new practices and frameworks that place more emphasis on data responsibility: the
label: BODY

text: safe, ethical and effective management of data. Data responsibility requires humanitarian
label: BODY

text: organizations and donors to take actions that help minimize risks and maximize benefits of data.
label: BODY

text: This is particularly challenging in cases where donors request personal and non-personal
label: BODY

text: sensitive data. This includes, for example, requests for personal data related to the screening of
label: BODY

text: aid recipients and requests for non-personal sensitive data for reporting on the delivery of
label: BODY

text: different forms of aid.
label: BODY

text: Humanitarian actors and donors recognize the risks and benefits associated with sharing such
label: BODY

text: data, but the sector has yet to establish a common understanding of how to balance these risks
label: BODY

text: and benefits effectively in the context of data sharing between humanitarians and donors. This
label: BODY

text: framework is designed to help advance data responsibility in this area.
label: BODY

text: III.
label: HH1

text: The Framework
label: BODY

text: Scope
label: HH1

text: The framework applies to situations where humanitarian organizations share disaggregated
label: BODY

text: data with donors. Disaggregated data refers to data that is broken down by one or more
label: BODY

text: sub-categories; e.g. sex, age, disability, location, etc. The framework covers personal and
label: BODY

text: non-personal sensitive data generated through or related to the delivery of humanitarian
label: BODY

text: assistance.
label: BODY

text: Objectives
label: HH1

text: This framework is designed to reinforce the overarching commitment to ‘do no harm’, while
label: BODY

text: minimizing the risks and maximizing the benefits of data in humanitarian action. It also aims to
label: BODY

text: support collective action for more responsible data sharing practices between humanitarian
label: BODY

text: organizations and donors.
label: BODY

text: Individual entities are encouraged to adapt this framework to their own institutional context,
label: BODY

text: including through relevant guidelines, procedures, templates and tools for data sharing where
label: BODY

text: appropriate. Adaptation and adoption of the framework should align with different donors’ and
label: BODY

text: humanitarian organizations’ respective mandates, relevant legal, policy and regulatory
label: BODY

text: frameworks, and the decisions of governing bodies.
label: BODY

text: 7 A list of definitions for the interpretation of this framework can be found in Annex A.
label: BODY

text: Guidelines for Responsible Data Sharing Between Humanitarian Organizations and
label: HH1

text: Donors
label: HH1

text: The following guidelines build on and complement existing principles and guidance for data
label: BODY

text: responsibility (including data protection) in humanitarian action. This includes the Inter-Agency
label: BODY

text: Standing Committee Operational Guidance on Data Responsibility and the ICRC Handbook on
label: BODY

text: Data Protection in Humanitarian Action. They also accounts for other frameworks for principled
label: BODY

text: humanitarian action, including the Good Humanitarian Donorship Initiative’s 24 Principles and
label: BODY

text: Good Practice of Humanitarian Donorship
label: BODY

text: and the Donor Cash Forum Statement and Guiding
label: BODY

text: Principles on Interoperability of Data Systems in Humanitarian Cash Programming.11
label: BODY

text: Prioritize rights and needs of affected populations.
label: BODY

text: Donors should request data from humanitarian organizations in ways that put the
label: BODY

text: rights and needs of affected populations at the center.
label: BODY

text: b. Humanitarian organizations should ensure that data sharing processes are
label: BODY

text: designed and implemented in ways that put the rights and needs of affected
label: BODY

text: populations at the center throughout the data lifecycle.
label: BODY

text: Humanitarian organizations should ensure the possibility for the affected
label: BODY

text: population to exercise their personal data protection rights, including the right to
label: BODY

text: information, the right to access, the right to correction and the right to erasure.
label: BODY

text: d. Humanitarian organizations should inform affected people about the planned
label: BODY

text: sharing of their data and ensure that affected people understand the full data
label: BODY

text: lifecycle’ (e.g., which entities will have access to the data at different stages and
label: BODY

text: for what purpose).
label: BODY

text: Humanitarian organizations should ensure, to the greatest possible extent,
label: BODY

text: adequate involvement of affected people in the design, implementation,
label: BODY

text: monitoring and evaluation of data management activities.
label: BODY

text: Specify and clearly communicate the purposes of data sharing and the type of
label: BODY

text: data required for these purposes in a given context.
label: BODY

text: Donors should specify and articulate the purposes of data sharing and the type of
label: BODY

text: disaggregated data required for these purposes for all data requests in a given
label: BODY

text: context.
label: BODY

text: b. Donors should uphold data minimization by only requesting the information
label: BODY

text: required to meet the specified purpose and striving to ensure that the data is not
label: BODY

text: used in any other way.
label: BODY

text: 11 Donor Cash Forum Statement and Guiding Principles on Interoperability of Data Systems in Humanitarian Cash Programming
label: BODY

text: (2022). Available here: https://www.calpnetwork.org/wp-content/uploads/ninja-forms/2/DCF-Interoperability-Statement-FINAL.pdf
label: BODY

text: 10 https://www.ghdinitiative.org/assets/files/GHD%20Principles%20and%20Good%20Practice/GHD%20Principles.pdf
label: BODY

text: 9 ​ICRC, Handbook on Data Protection in Humanitarian Action (2020). Available here:
label: BODY

text: https://www.icrc.org/en/data-protection-humanitarian-actionhandbook
label: BODY

text: 8 IASC Operational Guidance on Data Responsibility in Humanitarian Action (2021)). Available here::
label: BODY

text: https://interagencystandingcommittee.org/operational-response/iasc-operational-guidance-data-responsibility-humanitarian-action
label: BODY

text: Humanitarian organizations should document all requests for data and ensure
label: BODY

text: consistency in responding to these requests over time.
label: BODY

text: d. Donors should avoid making ad hoc requests for data that falls outside the terms
label: BODY

text: of established agreements and/or in addition to what is required to meet the
label: BODY

text: purpose(s) for data sharing as originally specified and agreed. Such requests
label: BODY

text: should always be made in writing and should specify which data is required, the
label: BODY

text: format desired, the intended use of the data, and the purposes of data sharing in
label: BODY

text: a given context.
label: BODY

text: Clarify and formalize requirements for responsible data sharing and establish
label: BODY

text: appropriate agreements to support implementation in different contexts.
label: BODY

text: Donors should clearly articulate their data requirements at the outset of a
label: BODY

text: collaboration, so that responsible data sharing practices can be agreed and
label: BODY

text: reflected in the grant agreement (and related documents). This includes
label: BODY

text: specifying the ways in which data should be handled by all parties involved
label: BODY

text: across the data lifecycle in-line with sector-wide standards.
label: BODY

text: b. Donors should monitor how these requirements are implemented in different
label: BODY

text: response environments as part of existing compliance and/or quality assurance
label: BODY

text: processes and offer support to their staff to foster consistent adherence to
label: BODY

text: agreed requirements over time.
label: BODY

text: Humanitarian organizations and donors should include clear terms for
label: BODY

text: responsible data sharing when negotiating relevant contracts and/or agreements,
label: BODY

text: including with third parties.
label: BODY

text: This includes defining responsibilities for responsible
label: BODY

text: data sharing throughout the data lifecycle and considerations regarding data
label: BODY

text: sensitivity, data security, and data retention and destruction, among others. The
label: BODY

text: terms should also account for context-specific policy, legal and regulatory
label: BODY

text: frameworks, as well as common protocols for responsible data sharing within the
label: BODY

text: humanitarian community (e.g. system-wide information sharing protocols).
label: BODY

text: Use a common approach for assessing and mitigating risks related to data
label: BODY

text: sharing specific to humanitarian contexts.
label: BODY

text: Humanitarian organizations and donors should conduct a data impact
label: BODY

text: assessment for different data sharing activities, accounting to context-specific
label: BODY

text: factors and dynamics that may influence the likelihood or severity of a risk related
label: BODY

text: to data sharing. This can be done jointly or by each collaborating organization.
label: BODY

text: b. Humanitarian organizations and donors should establish mitigation measures to
label: BODY

text: address potential risks related to data sharing, notably for the affected
label: BODY

text: populations and individuals or groups at risk.
label: BODY

text: Humanitarian organizations and donors should monitor the effectiveness of risk
label: BODY

text: mitigation measures throughout the course of the data sharing activity.
label: BODY

text: 12 This includes, inter alia, Third Party Monitors (TPMs), Financial Service Providers (FSPs), and individual and institutional
label: BODY

text: consultants involved in data management.
label: BODY

text: Invest in the capacity required to develop and uphold sector-wide approaches for
label: HH1

text: data responsibility throughout the data lifecycle.
label: BODY

text: Humanitarian organizations and donors should establish and maintain robust
label: BODY

text: policies and procedures for responsible data management. This includes
label: BODY

text: promoting the use of humanitarian standards and related frameworks for data
label: BODY

text: responsibility, such as the IASC Operational Guidance on Data Responsibility.
label: BODY

text: b. Humanitarian organizations and donors should establish appropriate tools and
label: BODY

text: services, including those required for data security across the different steps in
label: BODY

text: the data lifecycle.
label: BODY

text: Humanitarian organizations and donors should train staff on the requirements for
label: BODY

text: responsible data sharing and use. This should include clear instructions on how
label: BODY

text: the present framework applies in different operational settings and with different
label: BODY

text: counterparts.
label: BODY

text: d. Humanitarian organizations and donors should offer financial and technical
label: BODY

text: support to partners as required to uphold sector-wide standards for data
label: BODY

text: responsibility throughout the data lifecycle.
label: BODY

text: Contribute to joint advocacy, learning and development of additional guidelines
label: BODY

text: for responsible data sharing.
label: BODY

text: Humanitarian organizations and donors should proactively communicate about
label: BODY

text: the benefits of responsible data sharing, including lessons learned about
label: BODY

text: mitigating risks.
label: BODY

text: b. Humanitarian organizations and donors should support learning and
label: BODY

text: accountability initiatives for the safe, ethical and effective management of data in
label: BODY

text: humanitarian action.
label: BODY

text: Humanitarian organizations and donors should encourage regular evaluations of
label: BODY

text: how data is shared and used.
label: BODY

text: d. Humanitarian organizations and donors should invest in research to close gaps in
label: BODY

text: evidence related to the risks and benefits of data in humanitarian settings.
label: BODY

text: Humanitarian organizations and donors should assess whether there are implicit
label: BODY

text: conditionalities between the willingness to share disaggregated data and the
label: BODY

text: ability of different organizations to access and sustain funding, and take
label: BODY

text: corrective action to address this when identified.
label: BODY

text: Humanitarian organizations and donors should support inter-sectoral
label: BODY

text: collaboration across the humanitarian, development and peace nexus to foster
label: BODY

text: complementarity in approaches to data responsibility.
label: BODY

text: Annex A: Definitions
label: HH1

text: For the purposes of this framework, the following definitions apply:
label: BODY

text: “Data impact assessment” is a generic term that refers to multiple types of assessments. This includes
label: HH1

text: Data Protection Impact Assessments (DPIAs), the established tool and process in data protection law that
label: BODY

text: should be used (specifically) to assess personal data protection risks. Many organizations have specific
label: BODY

text: policies, requirements and guidelines for how DIAs should be conducted.
label: BODY

text: “Data Management” refers to the design of data management activities and subsequent collection or
label: HH1

text: receipt, storage, processing, analysis, sharing, use, and retention and destruction of data and information
label: BODY

text: by humanitarian actors. Such activities occur as part of humanitarian action throughout the planning and
label: BODY

text: response cycle across clusters/sectors and include, but are not limited to, situational analysis, needs
label: BODY

text: assessments, population data management, registration and enrollment, case management,
label: BODY

text: communicating with affected populations, protection monitoring, and response monitoring and evaluation.
label: BODY

text: “Data Responsibility’’ refers to the safe, ethical and effective management of personal and non-personal
label: HH1

text: data in humanitarian action.
label: BODY

text: “Data Sharing” includes all acts that make data accessible on paper, via electronic means or the internet,
label: BODY

text: or through other methods to a recipient: a natural or legal person, public authority, agency or another
label: BODY

text: body, to which the personal data is disclosed.
label: BODY

text: “Disaggregated data” refers to data that is broken down by one or more sub-categories; e.g. sex, age,
label: BODY

text: disability, location, etc. The framework includes personal and non-personal sensitive data generated
label: BODY

text: through or related to the delivery of humanitarian assistance.
label: BODY

text: “Donors” refers to entities who are major contributors to international and humanitarian organizations.
label: HH1

text: This may include states, private foundations, and other entities that provide financial resources to support
label: BODY

text: the delivery of humanitarian assistance.
label: BODY

text: “Humanitarian Organizations” refers to entities with a mission to alleviate human suffering and support
label: BODY

text: affected populations in situations of conflict, natural disaster or socio-economic hardship.
label: BODY

text: “Personal Data” means any information relating to an identified or identifiable natural person. An
label: HH1

text: identifiable natural person is one who can be identified, directly or indirectly, in particular by reference to
label: BODY

text: an identifier such as a name, an identification number, location data, an online identifier or to one or more
label: BODY

text: factors specific to the physical, physiological, genetic, mental, economic, cultural or social identity of that
label: BODY

text: natural person.
label: BODY

text: “Sensitive non-personal data” means information whose unauthorized disclosure may cause very
label: HH1

text: serious harm to humanitarian organizations’ or donors’ operations, reputation, assets, staff, and
label: BODY

text: interlocutors, or is very likely to result in regulatory action(s). Such information may also be defined as
label: BODY

text: sensitive due to its nature, regardless of the harm its unauthorized disclosure would cause to
label: BODY

text: humanitarian organizations’ or donors’.
label: BODY

text: “Third party” means a natural or legal person, public authority, agency or body other than the data
label: BODY

text: subject, controller, processor and persons who, under the direct authority of the controller or processor,
label: BODY

text: are authorized to process personal data.
label: BODY
